citations.narrative:
An open bag of dog food is not being stored appropriately to prevent contamination and spoilage. An open, bulk bag of
dog food that is used to refill the dog food container in the primary enclosure is being stored in a closet by itself and not
within a leakproof container with a tightly fitting lid. The closet is also located within the same room as the primary
enclosure. Open bags of food that are not stored in a container can become contaminated and spoil faster. Correct by
storing all open bags of food in leakproof containers with tightly fitting lids to prevent contamination and storage.
Additionally, ensure that only food which is currently being used is kept in animal areas.

The medical records for a 3-year-old, Labrador retriever “Stryker” (ID: 6000012345612), are missing routine husbandry
and treatments that have been performed. According to the program of veterinary care, Stryker’s preventative care
includes monthly nail trims and baths, weekly ear cleanings and teeth brushing, and brushing of his coat daily. There are
no medical records documenting nail trims, ear cleanings, teeth brushing, or brushing of his coat daily. The last
documented bath was in March of 2023. Accurate medical records that list all preventative care activities are necessary to
ensure that the licensee is following the program of veterinary care as directed by the attending veterinarian. Correct by
ensuring medical records are maintained for all routine husbandry, including preventative medical procedures or
treatments.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 17, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.1(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
An open bag of dog food is not being stored appropriately to prevent contamination and spoilage. An open, bulk bag of 
dog food that is used to refill the dog food container in the primary enclosure is being stored in a closet by itself and not 
within a leakproof container with a tightly fitting lid. The closet is also located within the same room as the primary 
enclosure. Open bags of food that are not stored in a container can become contaminated and spoil faster. Correct by 
storing all open bags of food in leakproof containers with tightly fitting lids to prevent contamination and storage. 
Additionally, ensure that only food which is currently being used is kept in animal areas. 
3.13(b)(1) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The medical records for a 3-year-old, Labrador retriever “Stryker” (ID: 6000012345612), are missing routine husbandry 
and treatments that have been performed. According to the program of veterinary care, Stryker’s preventative care 
includes monthly nail trims and baths, weekly ear cleanings and teeth brushing, and brushing of his coat daily. There are 
no medical records documenting nail trims, ear cleanings, teeth brushing, or brushing of his coat daily. The last 
documented bath was in March of 2023. Accurate medical records that list all preventative care activities are necessary to 
ensure that the licensee is following the program of veterinary care as directed by the attending veterinarian. Correct by 
ensuring medical records are maintained for all routine husbandry, including preventative medical procedures or 
treatments. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 17, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.

n
